intro: Lepidium virginicum subsp. texanum, commonly known as Texas peppergrass, is a flowering plant native to the central and southern United States. It is a low-growing annual herb that typically reaches heights of 10–30 centimeters. The plant produces small, yellow flowers arranged in racemes, which bloom from late spring to early summer. Its leaves are alternate, linear to lanceolate, and often have a slightly hairy texture. The seeds are enclosed in small, capsule-like fruits that split open to release the seeds when mature.
